stories.headline: 'It’s just unfair.' What end of TPS means for Nicaraguans and Hondurans in U.S.
stories.summary: Virginia Guevara, a Honduran immigrant, faces possible deportation after the Trump administration ended Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for more than 51,000 Hondurans. Many affected face emotional and financial hardship as they risk losing jobs and health insurance, while concerns grow over detainment conditions and deaths reported in immigration facilities.

stories.headline: ‘We are living through the most difficult times,’ Havana activists tell U.S. diplomats
stories.summary: At the anniversary of the July 11, 2021 protests in Cuba, activists and political prisoners' relatives demanded U.S. diplomatic support for freedom and democracy in Cuba. The event highlighted continued repression by Cuban authorities and called for international solidarity, with Cuban exiles encouraging hope and resistance despite governmental crackdowns.

stories.headline: Elon Musk’s brain chip was put in a patient at a hospital in Miami. What to know
stories.summary: A paralyzed military veteran became the first patient in Miami to have a brain chip implanted by Neuralink, co-founded by Elon Musk. The chip aims to help users control computers and electronic devices with their minds, potentially offering new independence and capabilities to those with paralysis.

stories.headline: Giant bugs, heat and a hospital visit: Inside Alligator Alcatraz’s first days
stories.summary: The newly opened Alligator Alcatraz detention center has faced criticism over harsh conditions including extreme temperatures, infestations of giant bugs, and inadequate access to hygiene and medical services. The facility, housing ICE detainees, is under scrutiny as stories from detainees and their families raise alarms about the treatment and human rights concerns associated with the center.

stories.headline: 'We are toast': Feds brace for more layoffs after ruling
stories.summary: Federal workers face increased anxiety about potential layoffs following a recent court ruling. Employees expressed concern over job security and benefits, highlighting ongoing tensions in federal workforce management and legal challenges affecting employment across government agencies.

stories.headline: Right-wing revolt in the West dooms GOP proposal to sell off public lands
stories.summary: Patrick Payne, a conservative Idaho outdoorsman, opposed a Republican plan to sell off up to 3.3 million acres of federal land in the West. His resistance reflects wider dissent within the party and amongst local citizens regarding the management and privatization of public lands, highlighting ongoing political debates about land use and conservation.

stories.headline: Revelations about decades of adoption fraud in South Korea impel a dizzying quest for the truth
stories.summary: Aaron Grzegorczyk uncovered a long-held family secret involving fraudulent adoptions in South Korea. His investigation reveals emotional family histories and sheds light on wider issues of adoption fraud documented by the South Korean government spanning decades.

stories.headline: Trump extends tariffs deadline
stories.summary: President Donald Trump extended the deadline for the 'Liberation Day' tariffs initially set for August 1. The administration pushed back the deadline after previously imposing tariffs and reignited debate on trade policies and their impact. The move has drawn scrutiny from CEOs, investors, and foreign leaders, with mixed reactions about its implications on global trade and negotiations.

stories.headline: In Texas, locating the missing becomes an unceasing task
stories.summary: After catastrophic flooding in Texas, at least 173 people remain unaccounted for. Search efforts continue along the Guadalupe River amidst challenging conditions and overturned vehicles. Volunteers and authorities work tirelessly to locate missing persons, with some families seeking closure after losing loved ones in the floods.

stories.headline: With DC 33 strike over, now the cleanup begins
stories.summary: After days of mounting trash and growing tensions, the city and blue-collar union DC 33 reached a deal. The mayor called for a 'healing time' as the strike, the first major city workers strike since 1986, ended with a new contract offering 3% raises annually, a $1,500 bonus, creation of a fifth step in the union pay scale, and potential 5% annual increases. The contract awaits ratification by union members, with some uncertain about its impact.

stories.headline: Floods take psychological toll on first responders amid grim scenes
stories.summary: In Texas, first responders engaged in search and recovery after devastating floods face accumulating mental health challenges. With over 160 people still missing, and many dead, officials report the emotional burden on rescue teams is significant amid difficult conditions and ongoing recovery efforts in Texas' Hill Country. The response mission impacts responders' ability to mentally recover while supporting survivors and families affected by the natural disaster.

stories.headline: In the crosshairs of cuts, federal workers live in fear of the ax
stories.summary: Following a Supreme Court ruling allowing President Trump to begin federal government job firings, many federal employees fear for their jobs. With layoffs expected at agencies including the State Department and Social Security Administration, workers face uncertainty and anxiety about potential dismissals during a chaotic governmental environment. The ruling brings a new phase of job loss amid political conflicts and challenges within federal institutions.

stories.headline: Pennie: 150,000 in Pa. could lose health insurance
stories.summary: Pennie, Pennsylvania's Obamacare marketplace, anticipates that as many as 150,000 people could lose health coverage next year if Congress does not extend enhanced tax credits, leading to premium spikes up to 82%. The coverage reductions stem from provisions in the Affordable Care Act that extend insurance to working Americans without employer insurance or Medicaid access. Loss of these credits could affect nearly 500,000 people enrolled in Pennie, many of whom currently pay affordable premiums.

stories.headline: Invasive carp reveal a surprising twist in national politics
stories.summary: The article discusses the ecological threat of invasive carp in the Great Lakes and their unexpected role in national politics. Initially introduced intentionally in the U.S. to control algae and waste treatment ponds, these carp have since spread extensively, impacting native species and ecosystems. The issue has gained bipartisan attention with both major political parties showing support for keeping invasive carp out of the Great Lakes through a physical barrier project at the Illinois River. The article also notes potential ecological consequences if the carp spread further and explores the intersection of environmental policy and political strategy regarding this invasive species.

stories.headline: State will delay building code updates amid lawsuits
stories.summary: Michigan will postpone using new construction codes designed to improve home energy efficiency in new buildings, following legal challenges from advocacy groups. The delay affects a decade-old initiative aimed at reducing utility bills and modernizing home construction standards. Local officials have agreed to delay implementing the new codes after lawsuits were filed in June by organizations representing home builders and modular and mobile home industries. The move postpones the update of standards that were intended to cut costs and improve sustainability in homebuilding.

stories.headline: Divisiveness remains on board 6 months after election
stories.summary: Six months after the Ottawa County Board of Commissioners election, divisiveness persists on the board despite new leadership and the departure of the Trump-aligned Ottawa Impact group's majority. The board remains split into two voting blocs: the remaining Ottawa Impact commissioners and other commissioners, which has led to disagreements on topics such as diversity, equity, inclusion, developer tax incentives, housing projects, and acceptance of certain federal grants. The divisiveness continues to influence the board's governance and decision-making.

stories.headline: Google eyes building a data center in SE Indy
stories.summary: Residents in southeast Indianapolis have been opposing a planned data center project by Google in their neighborhood. Google, a Fortune 100 company, is building several data centers in Indiana, but locals express concerns over the impact of this project. Documents obtained reveal the company has been pursuing this under secrecy, raising issues among residents.

stories.headline: Public media journalists to be laid off at end of the year
stories.summary: Indiana Public Broadcasting Stations will lay off an eight-person statewide reporting team by the end of the year as part of reorganization due to budget cuts. The layoff was announced via email, but the total number of staff loss remains unclear. Journalists and unions have expressed concerns over the impact on public media coverage across the state.

stories.headline: 'It's a legacy of disinvestment' - ATM near Black church ignites debate about Indy bank's lending disparities
stories.summary: A new ATM planned in a predominantly Black neighborhood of Indianapolis, near the National Bank of Indianapolis, has sparked debate about the bank’s lending disparities. The dispute involves calls for the bank to open a full-service branch to address longstanding issues of lending inequity towards African American homebuyers in Marion County. The discussion highlights persistent historical lending discrimination in the county.

stories.headline: Indy councilman is accused of abuse
stories.summary: Keith Graves, a Democratic member of the Indianapolis City-County Council, is accused of domestic abuse by Laurin Embry. Embry alleges abuse between 2020 and 2022 during their relationship. Graves denies the allegations and no criminal charges have been filed. Embry, also a social worker and Democratic campaign volunteer, discusses the impact of these allegations and the ongoing debate within local Democrats.

stories.headline: An outcry on behalf of Native women
stories.summary: At a public safety forum in Minneapolis, Indigenous women leaders and advocates called on city officials to declare a state of emergency due to the crisis of missing Native women. Native women make up less than 1% of Minnesota's population but accounted for over 10% of missing women cases between 2010-2019. The Minnesota Indian Women's Resource Center highlighted the lack of resources and systemic underresponse to these cases. The Minneapolis health commissioner and other officials acknowledged the issue, emphasizing the need for better law enforcement responses and data collection to address the high rates of violence against Indigenous people.

stories.headline: Ken Martin unpacks his rocky start as DNC chair
stories.summary: Democratic National Committee Chair Ken Martin discusses challenges he has faced since taking leadership, including managing internal party conflicts and criticism over fundraising difficulties. Despite a difficult start marked by public disagreements and strategic frustrations, Martin remains focused on uniting the party and addressing the concerns of grassroots activists. He acknowledges the ongoing anxiety and desire for stronger party momentum.

stories.headline: State disability research faces funding threat
stories.summary: Minnesota’s only federally funded research center dedicated to people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, the Institute on Community Integration, faces a possible funding cut. The center is vital for research and training programs but depends heavily on federal dollars, which may be withdrawn by the Trump administration. Without funding, community-based programs and advocacy efforts could end, potentially affecting disabled people and institutions statewide.

stories.headline: Walz testimony in D.C. racked up $430K bill
stories.summary: Minnesota taxpayers are on the hook for $430,000 in legal costs linked to Gov. Tim Walz's preparation for a U.S. House Oversight Committee hearing on immigration. The state hired global law firm K&L Gates for legal support. The State's Office confirmed the expenses and said the costs were necessary due to the hearing’s sensitive nature. Some Republicans criticized the expenditure, while Walz's spokesperson defended it, noting political motives behind the investigations.

stories.headline: Court finds Russia guilty of human rights atrocities
stories.summary: The European Court of Human Rights delivered damning judgments against Russia for war crimes and human rights violations in Ukraine, including the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in 2014. The court ruled Russia responsible for widespread violations such as killing and terrorizing civilians and illegally sabotaging infrastructure. Ukraine hailed the ruling as historic and an undeniable victory. Russia dismissed the judgment as symbolic and vowed not to abide by it.

stories.headline: Trump tariffs goods from Brazil at 50%, citing 'witch hunt' trial of country's ex-president
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has imposed 50% tariffs on Brazilian imports, singling out Brazil over its treatment of former President Jair Bolsonaro, who is currently facing a trial. Trump framed the tariffs as a response to what he sees as a politically motivated prosecution of Bolsonaro for allegedly trying to overturn Brazil's 2022 presidential election. The move highlights ongoing tensions in US-Brazil trade relations under Trump.

stories.headline: How conservatives beat back a Republican sell-off of public lands
stories.summary: Conservative activists and legislators have mobilized to oppose efforts to sell public lands, viewing the protection of these areas as a symbol of American greatness. Former Senator Donald Lee and allies countered proposals to auction off millions of acres, arguing for the preservation of federal lands for future generations. This movement highlights continuing political debates over land use and conservation in the US.

stories.headline: Former Alaska ICE detainee in Tacoma hospital with tuberculosis
stories.summary: A Peruvian asylum seeker who was previously detained in Alaska is currently hospitalized in Tacoma, Washington with tuberculosis. The man was part of a group of about 40 federal immigration detainees transferred from Alaska's Cook Inlet Pretrial Facility to Tacoma. Officials said there is no evidence of a larger outbreak, and that detainees had been screened for the illness. The case has raised questions about prison health protocols amid immigration detention.

stories.headline: Harrowing stories of rescue emerge from Texas floods
stories.summary: Devastating floods in Hunt, Texas, have left more than 160 people missing and caused widespread destruction. Rescue workers are digging through debris piles spanning miles to find survivors. First responders have reported numerous dramatic rescues, including people stranded on rooftops and clinging to trees in floodwaters.

stories.headline: This summer, it's bears vs. chickens on the Anchorage Hillside
stories.summary: Local biologists report increasing conflicts between brown bears and backyard chickens on Anchorage's Hillside. Since May, a brown bear sow and her two yearlings raided at least a dozen unsecured chicken coops, causing damage by smashing structures and killing chickens. Surveillance videos have documented these events, leading Fish and Game to encourage residents to use electric fences and other deterrents to protect their poultry.

stories.headline: Texas can release 2024 A-F grades
stories.summary: Texas can release its 2024 A-F accountability grades for public schools after a court ruled last week to dismiss a lawsuit by several districts. The 15th Court of Appeals allows the Texas Education Agency to issue its second set of campus ratings since 2019. The release of these academic accountability ratings had been paused recently due to lawsuits and COVID-19 limitations. These ratings evaluate every public school and district across Texas, providing families a feel for their local campuses' performance as well as impacting analyses of property tax spending and workforce recruitment. TEA officials recently won the ability to publish the 2023 scores, and state officials are reviewing when the 2024 ratings will be released. Several districts sued TEA claiming prior flawed results should invalidate the grades.

stories.headline: Nvidia hits critical milestone
stories.summary: Nvidia's shares briefly touched $4 trillion market capitalization, capping a stunning growth since its 2000 IPO. The stock's price has jumped over 1,000% since October 2022, boosted by Nvidia's dominance in AI chip technology – seen as the new world's most valuable company. Despite a recent decline from this high, Nvidia remains a top tech leader, continuously growing its market cap and establishing itself as a titan in semiconductors and AI infrastructure. This milestone cements Nvidia's position as a leader driving the tech field forward.

stories.headline: Trump ties 50% tariff to trial
stories.summary: President Donald Trump singled out Brazil over tariffs as he pressured to end a 'witch hunt' against former president Jair Bolsonaro. Trump accused the U.S. leaders of using tariffs as leverage in Bolsonaro's trial efforts and mentioned his strong informal ties to Bolsonaro. Bolsonaro is facing court hearings and challenges linked to election losses and the 2022 power shift in Brazil. The president warned that the tariff treatment, which could rise to 50%, is tied to Bolsonaro's legal battles. Bolsonaro testified before the Supreme Court, remaining in power with support from some Brazilian judges and officials.

stories.headline: Weather service jobs go unfilled
stories.summary: Key positions at National Weather Service offices across Texas remain vacant, with five of 33 spots unfilled in Dallas-Fort Worth alone. Hurricane-prone Houston is missing a meteorologist-in-charge, responsible for crucial forecasting during disasters. A total of 13 staff meteorologists are missing state-wide. The shortage hampers the ability to respond to natural disasters like the recent floods. Although vacancies pose community risks, officials emphasize there remains ample warning time to evacuate. The gap in staffing complicates issuing warnings, storm surveys, and coordination. Local officials and weather experts highlight this is a real concern for public safety.

stories.headline: Abbott packs agenda
stories.summary: Governor Greg Abbott has outlined special session items focusing on the deadly Hill Country floods, congressional redistricting, and the consumable hemp industry. Issued via a proclamation, Abbott highlighted improving early warning systems and infrastructure in flood zones, beefing up emergency communications, providing federal funding for affected areas including federal matching dollars, and updating or streamlining state preparedness and recovery procedures as key issues. The agenda aims to better prepare Texas for disaster events like the devastating July 4 flooding along the Guadalupe River and more.

stories.headline: Microsoft pledges $4B to AI education
stories.summary: Microsoft commits to donating $4 billion over the next five years to enhance artificial intelligence education through a new initiative called Microsoft Elevate. The program aims to help over 20 million people earn AI credentials with the help of about 300 employees, expanding Microsoft's philanthropy efforts in technology and education.

stories.headline: With report on deadly Air India crash possibly days away, focus shifts to key 787 switches
stories.summary: Investigators anticipate releasing preliminary findings soon on the fatal Air India Boeing 787 crash, with attention turning to potential issues involving key switches on 787 aircraft. The investigation follows guidelines from the International Civil Aviation Organization and aims for a preliminary report within 30 days of the accident.

stories.headline: ‘It’s not lost. It’s changed’
stories.summary: Two years ago, the Lookout fire burned through Oregon's H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest, damaging many research sites. Scientists report the forest has not been lost but changed, with the fire costing at least $800,000 in damage and impacting long-term research in the area. Researchers now study the aftermath to understand forest recovery and climate change impacts.

stories.headline: State will backfill $11M in federal cuts to Planned Parenthood, Ferguson says
stories.summary: Washington governor Bob Ferguson announced plans to restore about $11 million in federal funding lost due to presidential budget cuts impacting local Planned Parenthood services. The state intends to safeguard healthcare access for affected communities despite federal restrictions on abortion-related funding.

stories.headline: U.S. measles cases reach highest total since 2000
stories.summary: The U.S. has seen the highest number of measles cases since 2000 with over 2,000 cases in 2025 reported, an alarming increase linked to declining childhood vaccination rates. The CDC warns this resurgence presents a significant public health challenge as measles spreads to communities with low immunity.
people: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

stories.headline: Harrowing stories of rescue emerge as search continues
stories.summary: Following massive floods in Texas caused by a wall of water engulfing camps and homes, rescue efforts continue amid tragic losses. Reports include a police officer trapped and stranded on rooftops, a fellow officer tying a garden hose to reach stranded people, and firsthand accounts of horrific conditions. More than 160 people remain missing, with at least 115 dead. The flooding is the deadliest inland flood in the U.S. since 1976, with extensive damage ongoing and uncertainty about the full extent of the catastrophe.

stories.headline: Pepper targets Jackson
stories.summary: Councilman Hunter Pepper has filed legal and ethics complaints with the state against Councilman Billy Jackson over alleged damage to Jackson's mayoral candidate home by a car in 2022. Pepper, who is not running for reelection, claims Jackson's home is condemned and violates city codes. The Decatur Peppert Cover Up email suggests that Jackson's preferential treatment by the Community Development Department has caused controversy related to his qualification papers for mayor.

stories.headline: Sweet knowledge
stories.summary: The Sweetly Camp at Calhoun Community College in Decatur is introducing girls in grades 9 through 12 to careers in skilled trades like welding, electrical mechanics, and 3D printing. The camp, hosted by the Decatur-Morgan County Chamber of Commerce in partnership with Calhoun Community College, emphasizes safety and technology skills, giving girls hands-on experience and opportunities to build projects. The camp has graduated approximately 468 students and aims to encourage girls to pursue careers in the growing skilled trades industries.

stories.headline: AG pushes for trial of ex-officer
stories.summary: A former Decatur police officer, Mac Marquette, charged with murder for shooting a man during a tow truck dispute, failed to show clear legal right to prosecutorial immunity in a court filing by Attorney General Steve Marshall. The officer and two others accompanied the tow truck driver to repossess a pickup truck when Marquette fired 18 bullets after the officers emerged from a concealed position, leading to a legal battle over immunity and trial fate in Alabama's 'stand your ground' law context.

stories.headline: Transportation secretary to step down
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore announced that Maryland Department of Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld will step down from his position effective August 1. The change in leadership comes as part of a transition in the state's transportation administration.

stories.headline: Police release bodycam footage of fatal shooting
stories.summary: The Baltimore Police Department released body-worn camera footage of an officer-involved shooting that occurred on June 25 involving Pytrorcarcha Brooks, who was wielding a knife. The footage shows officers responding to a call about a woman armed with a weapon. Officers shot Brooks after she lunged at them despite efforts to deescalate the situation with a Taser. Police and officials are reviewing the incident amidst a backdrop of nearby construction noise that complicated the audio.

stories.headline: Trump sets tariffs on several nations
stories.summary: President Donald Trump imposed a 25% tax on goods imported from Japan and South Korea, among other nations, effective August 1. This move is part of a broader effort to raise tariffs and reduce federal bureaucracy, affecting several countries and raising concerns about inflation. The White House economic council noted that prices of imported goods have decreased, contradicting fears of tariff-driven inflation.

stories.headline: Maryland sees 8 heat-related deaths in June
stories.summary: Eight people in Maryland have died from heat-related causes in June, according to the Maryland Department of Health. The rising temperatures and emergency room visits have raised concerns about heat safety and public health.

stories.headline: Study: Jewish population never fully recovered from Holocaust
stories.summary: A new study by the Pew Research Center shows that the global Jewish population is only slightly higher today than in 2010 but remains far below pre-Holocaust levels. Before 1939, the Jewish population was about 16.6 million, but it fell to around 5.85 million in Europe by 1951 due to systematic murder by the Nazis. The study highlights ongoing demographic changes and the impact of historical trauma on the Jewish community.

stories.headline: Biden's ex-doctor doesn't answer questions
stories.summary: President Joe Biden's White House physician has declined to answer questions related to the ongoing House Republican investigation into Biden's health. The lack of response has drawn attention amid political scrutiny.

stories.headline: Residents fed up with addiction in Morrell Park
stories.summary: Residents in Baltimore's Morrell Park neighborhood expressed frustration about addiction issues after a 7-year-old child was found with a dirty needle in a backyard. The incident occurred during a Fourth of July cookout and raised concerns about the community's safety. The family is speaking out, and neighbors are calling attention to ongoing struggles with drug addiction in the area.

stories.headline: Baltimore man guilty of murder in conspiracy
stories.summary: A Baltimore man, Keon Wilson-Hawkins, was found guilty of conspiring to kill his estranged husband with the help of his great aunt, Frances Hamilton. The victim, Brice Boots, was fatally stabbed in 2024 after a troubled relationship and an incident in an abandoned SUV. The prosecutor called the murder personal and brutal, with a jury finding Wilson-Hawkins guilty of first-degree premeditated murder and other charges.

stories.headline: Reese Flying Sky High: Nabs Cover of NBA 2K26 Video Game, Has Her New Signature Shoe Unveiled
stories.summary: Reese has achieved a milestone by landing on the cover of the NBA 2K26 video game and unveiling her new signature shoe, highlighting her rising prominence in sports.

stories.headline: Judge Rules Indicted Former Ald. Carrie Austin Medically Unfit to Stand Trial
stories.summary: A judge has ruled that former Alderman Carrie Austin, who is indicted, is medically unfit to stand trial.

stories.headline: City Landmarks Panel to Weigh Revitalization of Field Building for Mixed Use
stories.summary: The City Landmarks Panel is set to consider the revitalization plans for the Field Building located at 135 S. LaSalle St., aiming for mixed-use development in the area.

stories.headline: Homeland Insecurity
stories.summary: DHS agents swarmed outside the National Museum of Puerto Rican Arts & Culture in Humboldt Park, causing panic among immigrants ahead of two festivals. Local officials labeled the incident as a scare tactic, while federal authorities stated it was connected to a drug investigation.

stories.headline: Election office hit over ballots
stories.summary: The top election official in Wisconsin's capital city was accused of unlawful conduct after failing to ensure nearly 200 absentee ballots were properly counted during the 2024 presidential election, according to a Wisconsin Elections Commission investigation. The report blasts former Madison Clerk Maribeth Witzel-Behl for 'profound failure' in handling absentee ballots and not acting after errors were learned, which undermines public confidence in elections.

stories.headline: Van Orden claims he helped WI hospitals get money
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Derrick Van Orden claimed victory over the passage of President Trump's tax cuts and spending bill, crediting himself for helping to secure Medicaid funding to avoid coverage losses for thousands of Wisconsinites. Funding increases were planned before Rep. Van Orden voted to cut Medicaid, but he said he 'helped secure' $1 billion annually in Medicaid for Wisconsin and worked with Gov. Tony Evers on state budget issues. His office denies blocking efforts ahead of federal dollars being secured.

stories.headline: Trial for Judge Dugan now likely months away
stories.summary: The federal obstruction case against Milwaukee County Judge Hannah Dugan, initially set for a fast-tracked trial, has been pushed back with a new trial date likely this year or in 2026. Both sides agreed to scrap the initial July 21 fast-tracked date. A hearing on July 9 clarified the slow trial timeline. Roughly 100 local protesters voiced their support outside the federal courthouse during the hearing, where the judge suspended from office awaits proceedings.

stories.headline: Former White House doctor pleads the Fifth on Biden acuity
stories.summary: Dr. Kevin O'Connor, former White House physician, has declined to answer questions from House lawmakers investigating President Biden's alleged cognitive decline by invoking the Fifth Amendment. Dr. O'Connor reportedly made a sudden exit from a House office interview and had been subpoenaed due to accusations of enabling President Biden's impaired cognitive state while in office, raising questions about transparency and protection of presidential health information.

stories.headline: Papadopoulos: Justice has 'airtight' case in Russia probe
stories.summary: George Papadopoulos, former 2016 Trump campaign staffer, claims the Justice Department's probe into the Trump campaign and Russia is 'airtight' with substantial evidence implicating former CIA Director John O. Brennan and FBI Director James B. Comey for promoting false narratives. Papadopoulos alleges that despite numerous repeated discussions between President Trump and foreign leaders, no legal case has been brought against key figures. He defends his own role and points to ongoing investigations and related legal developments.

stories.headline: Russian drone attacks' intensity illustrates Ukraine need for U.S. aid
stories.summary: A recent surge in Russian drone attacks on Ukraine, including one targeting Lutsk and others attacking Kyiv, underscores Ukraine's dire need for advanced U.S. military and defensive support. Analysts suggest that the intensity and persistence of the attacks demonstrate both Russia's weapon capabilities and Ukraine's urgent requirement for ongoing U.S. military aid, including technology, organization, and communication improvements to effectively counter Russia's offensives.

stories.headline: 99% of immigrant parolees remain here
stories.summary: A case study reveals that just 1% of illegal immigrants caught and released in a special test case two years ago have left the U.S. The Department of Homeland Security data shows that 99% of immigrant parolees remain in the country, with only 28 out of 2,572 immigrants having left by May 2023. The data highlights challenges in immigration enforcement and efforts to stem the Biden border surge, emphasizing that many immigrants have not been formally deported even after failing to report to ICE or receive formal documentation.

stories.headline: Oh, Superman, where are you from now?
stories.summary: Conservatives criticize the new 'Superman' film, especially its immigration theme portraying the hero as an immigrant, a change from previous interpretations. Director James Gunn explains the narrative choice as a story about kindness and humanity beyond political messages, but conservative critics say the movie frames Superman's character around immigration politics. The debate reflects broader cultural tensions surrounding representation and immigration.

stories.headline: As tax credit wanes, solar installers plan end-of-year sprint
stories.summary: With the impending expiration of a long-standing federal tax credit for residential solar projects, Maine's solar installation companies anticipate a surge in demand for rooftop panels before the deadline. The residential clean energy credit currently offers a federal tax credit worth 30% of the cost of a new solar system but may change, prompting installers to brace for a burst of requests despite uncertainty ahead.

stories.headline: Planned Parenthood turns to state to offset budget cuts
stories.summary: Planned Parenthood of Northern New England is seeking state governments in Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont to help offset funding shortfalls caused by a recent Republican budget bill. The federal law cut funding for the social service agency's non-abortion care, prompting leadership to ask states for assistance with health services for reproductive health care. The CEO, Nicole Clegg, also mentioned ongoing efforts to protect state's funding amid challenges including Medicaid and state requests.

stories.headline: EXPERTS URGE CAUTION, TRAINING AFTER SPATE OF WATER EMERGENCIES
stories.summary: Maine officials and water safety advocates are warning about the increased risk of water emergencies this summer due to fewer lifeguards, declining swimming education, and cold water temperatures despite warm air. Several drownings in the state recently highlight these dangers, stressing the need for caution and preparedness among swimmers and boaters. Experts emphasize the community's role in water safety to prevent further incidents.

stories.headline: For higher education in Maine, impact of megabill looms
stories.summary: President Trump's Republican-backed tax and spending bill signed into law has significant implications for Maine's higher education institutions, including medical school to liberal arts colleges. The One Big Beautiful Bill Act rolls back federal student loan access, eliminates repayment programs, adjusts college endowment taxes, and creates a new financial aid program. While proponents say it will make higher education more affordable by imposing accountability in student debt, some leaders fear negative impacts on accessibility and affordability of graduate programs.

stories.headline: 160 said still missing, 118 dead from floods
stories.summary: Over 160 people remain missing and at least 118 dead after devastating floods in the Hill Country region of Texas. Rescue crews are searching for survivors, navigating treacherous debris-filled waters and high floodwaters. Police report numerous rescues and ongoing search efforts as displaced residents seek safety amid a major natural disaster.

stories.headline: State still seeking work rule waiver
stories.summary: Arkansas Department of Human Services has submitted a waiver request to the federal government to avoid enforcing new work requirements tied to Medicaid eligibility starting in 2026. The department stated there are no current plans to withdraw the waiver and continues to work to meet federal requirements, despite pressures following recent federal legislation requiring work or training for many Medicaid enrollees.

stories.headline: Shops given notice of state delta-8 ban
stories.summary: The Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration has notified lawmakers and businesses about the imminent enforcement of a ban on delta-8 THC products. Delta-8 products will be removed from shelves and making such products available will no longer be allowed under a new 2023 state law aimed at controlling intoxicating hemp products. Legal appeals are underway but the state is moving forward with enforcement measures.
people: Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration

stories.headline: 5 West African leaders gather at White House
stories.summary: President Donald Trump hosted a meeting with five West African leaders to foster aid and trade ties. The leaders from Liberia, Senegal, Gabon, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau met to discuss economic priorities including minerals, oil deposits, and regional conflicts. Trump described the nations as vibrant partners and emphasized the U.S. commitment to strengthening relations in Africa.

stories.headline: Trump targets Brazil for 50% import taxes
stories.summary: President Donald Trump singled out Brazil for import taxes of 50%, citing treatment of its former president Jair Bolsonaro. Trump justified the tariffs based on Brazil's economic policies and actions perceived as harmful to U.S. interests, including intellectual property and trade agreements. Brazil's president Geraldo Alckmin criticized Trump's approach but mentioned no retaliatory actions by the U.S. were anticipated. Lula, the ex-leader referred to, defended Brazil’s sovereignty and opposed the tariffs as unjust.

stories.headline: Don’t add hoaxes, hate to the hurt of families
stories.summary: The article warns against the cruelty of online hoaxes and hateful responses targeting victims and their families of the Camp Mystic disaster. Many girls attending the camp have endured harmful social media attention, which only adds to their trauma. The commentary calls for compassion and advises against spreading misinformation and hateful content.

stories.headline: Six ways lawmakers may address flood risk
stories.summary: With devastating floods causing loss and damage, Texas lawmakers plan a special session to discuss new measures to mitigate flood risk. Governor Greg Abbott has included disaster response and recovery in the agenda. The Legislature aims to fix flaws in emergency warning systems and implement other policies to prevent similar tragedies in the future.

stories.headline: Questions lingering over the response, warnings
stories.summary: As investigations continue into the Kerr County floods, questions remain about whether camp staff followed safety plans and if officials issued alerts in time. Authorities and leaders at Camp Mystic are reviewing emergency procedures and evacuation plans after the disaster caused fatalities and missing persons, with officials still conducting recovery operations.

stories.headline: Community gathers to mourn flood victim
stories.summary: The community of Porter came together to mourn the death of Reese Manchaca, a 21-year-old college student and Caney Creek High School graduate, who died in the July 4 flood. A procession of first responders, family, and community members returned his body to Porter for burial, highlighting the tragic impact of the flooding disaster around Independence Day.

stories.headline: Foo's Fabulous Frozen Custard to get new owners
stories.summary: Foo's Fabulous Frozen Custard, a popular local custard shop in Brookside, is transitioning to new ownership after being run by Betty Bremser since 1996. Megan Reilly, a friend and alum of the original owner, along with two others, have become the new owners and intend to continue the business traditions while putting their own mark on Foo's. The change marks both a continuation and a new chapter for the beloved local treat spot.

stories.headline: Former students recount behavior after Truman teacher arrest
stories.summary: Former students of Truman High School recall their experiences after a beloved theater teacher, Austin Meyer, was arrested on charges of child pornography. The students share their shock and heartbreak over the allegations against Meyer, who was well-regarded for his dedication to drama and musical programs. The article touches on the impact of the arrest on the community and the subsequent investigation details.

stories.headline: Historic Kansas City bell tower might be removed
stories.summary: The 40-foot tall bell tower at Sisters of Loretto Academy, a historic building in Kansas City, may be removed due to structural concerns. The building, now used as event space and apartments, has weathered deteriorating conditions. Preservationist groups and the building's owner debate its fate amid safety concerns and preservation efforts, with a certificate of appropriateness requested for removal and permanent display of the tower below the current location.

stories.headline: Jackson County proposes date for White recall election
stories.summary: Jackson County legislators voted unanimously to set a special election on August 26 to decide whether to recall Executive Frank White from his position. The vote aims to provide residents an initiative to express their stance on White's recall, despite controversy over the legality and broader political implications of the effort involving a new Royals stadium tax proposal. Some dismiss the recall as a vendetta, while White challenges the scheduling legality.

stories.headline: Temperatures soar to a record-breaking 118 degrees
stories.summary: Phoenix hit a record high temperature of 118 degrees on July 9, breaking the previous daily record by 2 degrees and exceeding the normal high by 11 degrees. The National Weather Service issued extreme heat warnings for 11 counties in Arizona due to this scorching weather. Meteorologists warn that many desert areas could see more records broken as the summer heat continues, fueled by high-pressure systems and limited moisture in the air as the official monsoon season approaches.

stories.headline: Clean energy sector's future murky after law's passage
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's new federal spending and tax law is expected to have significant impacts on Arizona's clean energy sector. The legislation, pushed through by Republicans, could cripple the industry by sharply reducing tax credits for solar and wind, with longer phase-outs for hydropower, nuclear energy, and other carbon-free power generation. This shift may lead to higher costs and slower momentum for renewable energy initiatives, raising concerns among some industry experts and stakeholders.

stories.headline: Searchers scour for more than 170 still missing in Texas flooding
stories.summary: Over 170 people remain missing following severe flooding in Texas, with officials scrambling to rescue and locate victims days after the July 4 flash floods claimed at least 119 lives. Search and rescue teams, including counselors and volunteers, are focused on hard-hit areas such as the Christian camp along the river and Kern County alone. The death toll has risen and further hampered by ongoing storms and hot weather conditions that complicate rescue efforts. Authorities are investigating and monitoring conditions closely as recovery continues.

stories.headline: CSU reduces named storms in latest forecast
stories.summary: Colorado State University has lowered its prediction for the number of named storms and hurricanes this season from 17 to 13, including three major hurricanes. This follows Tropical Storm Barry's floods in Texas and addresses concerns about weather forecast funding cuts and early retirements within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration under the Trump administration. Despite these cuts, meteorologists still expect a busy hurricane season.

stories.headline: County OKs renaming road to Mar-a-Lago after Trump
stories.summary: Palm Beach County commissioners voted unanimously to rename a part of Southern Boulevard to 'President Donald J. Trump Boulevard,' despite some resident pushback. The renamed stretch covers an area near Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate and honors local sheriff's deputies. The decision follows Governor Ron DeSantis signing a related bill earlier in the year.

stories.headline: Trump strips protected status for Hondurans
stories.summary: The Trump administration has ended Temporary Protected Status for 72,000 Hondurans and 4,000 Nicaraguans, putting them at risk of deportation. This follows similar actions affecting Venezuelans and Haitians. Officials cited storm damage and political conditions as reasons for ending protections, while some federal courts may delay the end of TPS for affected populations.

stories.headline: PBC board courts NYC execs after Mamdani win
stories.summary: Palm Beach County's Business Development Board responded to New York City mayoral candidate Zorhan Mamdani's primary win by working to assemble 500 relocation packets for Big Apple executives. The initiative aims to capitalize on Mamdani's victory to attract new businesses and foster a more business-friendly environment in Palm Beach County.

stories.headline: State’s I-24 plan draws pushback
stories.summary: Some Chattanooga area residents expressed opposition to the Tennessee Department of Transportation's plan to widen a segment of Interstate 24, arguing it will not solve traffic bottleneck issues. While officials say the widening could alleviate traffic congestion, residents feel that adding lanes doesn't necessarily improve traffic flow and prefer investment in railways to reduce truck traffic on highways. The state has allocated $246 million for a 10-mile stretch widening project, with possible work starting in 2027 or 2028 and ending in 2027 according to a 10-year plan.

stories.headline: Planning head resigns after probe
stories.summary: Dan Reuter, Chattanooga's top planner, resigned after an administrative leave following reports about his behavior at work. He reportedly verbally attacked colleagues during meetings and made demeaning and belittling comments. The city’s Human Resources department indicated that such treatment, especially towards women, was observed consistently, sometimes with incident but generally over time.

stories.headline: Judge: Closed meetings violated state law
stories.summary: A judge ruled in favor of the Chattanooga Times Free Press in a lawsuit against the city of Chattanooga, finding that city council members violated open meetings laws by holding secret meetings about redistricting local voting districts. The Chattanooga City Council is now required to follow the Tennessee Open Meetings Act and submit one year of oversight reports. The ruling was appreciated by the Times Free Press editor as a win for government transparency and public oversight.

stories.headline: Flooding claims 119 lives as search for missing continues
stories.summary: Officials in Kerr County, Texas, are still responding to a devastating flood that swept through the Texas Hill Country nearly a week ago, killing at least 119 people statewide. The majority of deaths were in Kerr County with 95 confirmed deaths and 161 people still missing. Search efforts continue for missing persons amid disaster response preparations. Governor Greg Abbott announced a special legislative session focusing on disaster preparedness as the state copes with the aftermath.

stories.headline: Residency at issue in mayor race
stories.summary: New television ads for Detroit mayoral hopeful the Rev. Solomon Kinloch highlight the time as a young boy that he and his family struggled with poverty and lived in an abandoned house in the city. Since those humble beginnings, Kinloch has lived in different parts of Oakland County and most recently moved into an upscale residential downtown condo complex with his brother. Kinloch, 52, became a registered voter in Detroit in March 2024, according to state and city records.

stories.headline: Italian candymaker set to buy WK Kellogg
stories.summary: WK Kellogg Co., the Michigan cereal giant, is set to be acquired by the Italian candymaker leader Ferrero Rocher in a nearly $3 billion deal. Shares in Kellogg surged more than 50% after-hours trading upon news of the deal. Ferrero’s acquisition would be its second major U.S. acquisition with the previous purchase of Battle Creek cereal and snack manufacturer. This deal comes amid scrutiny of WK Kellogg's products by health officials over nutritional concerns.

stories.headline: Vaccinations dip in Mich. as waiver rates rise
stories.summary: The number of Michigan students with vaccine waivers has nearly doubled since the COVID-19 pandemic, as fewer children get their recommended vaccines. Data from the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services shows more than 21,800 waivers in 2024 compared to 11,400 in 2020. About 3.4% of more than 338,000 total students in certain grades received waivers last year. Health officials warn this trend could increase susceptibility to infectious disease outbreaks in schools.

stories.headline: Step inside FedEx’s huge distribution hub
stories.summary: Romulus — FedEx recently opened a new massive distribution hub using an automated conveyor system to scan, sort, and prep packages to be flown in the next destination. The facility, nearly twice the size of the previous ramp at Detroit Metro Airport, enables the loading of about 12,000 packages an hour, faster and more efficiently. This $420 million investment significantly enhances FedEx’s automation capabilities and is part of its expansion efforts in the U.S.

stories.headline: Sheriff's partnership with ICE stirs rancor
stories.summary: Butler County Sheriff Pauline Peluso's agreement with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has sparked controversy among residents, many of whom oppose the partnership due to concerns about increasing deportation campaigns. Ms. Peluso defends the partnership as reflecting law enforcement priorities and believes the criticism is unwarranted.

stories.headline: Pa. Dems hope to capitalize on GOP bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's tax and budget bill has energized Democrats in Pennsylvania, who argue the cuts to Medicaid, SNAP, and other programs will harm working and low-income residents. Democrats see the bill as a rallying cry for the 2026 midterm elections, while local officials and political committees are strategizing how to target vulnerable Republican lawmakers.

stories.headline: Secret Service punished 6 agents
stories.summary: Six U.S. Secret Service members were suspended without pay or benefits following the attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Butler County. The suspensions ranged from 10 to 42 days, with agents restricted to less operational roles. The discipline process was federally mandated, and recently agents were given the right to appeal.

stories.headline: Shapiro's flight use questioned
stories.summary: Republican senator Jarrett Coleman questions the use of a state-chartered plane by Governor Josh Shapiro, focusing on transparency and the cost to taxpayers. There are concerns regarding the proper use and disclosure of state-funded aircraft trips.

stories.headline: Victims slam Govoni prosecutor's firing
stories.summary: Families whose trust funds were stolen express concern that Pam Bondi's decision to fire the lead prosecutor in the Leo Govoni embezzlement case could negatively impact the progress of the case. Nearly $200,000 was taken from a disabled daughter's medical trust fund. The firing has drawn criticism amid ongoing legal proceedings.

stories.headline: Candidate Orlando Gudes may qualify for residency
stories.summary: Orlando Gudes, a former Tampa City Council member and candidate for the District 5 seat, faces scrutiny over whether he meets residency requirements. His address was changed weeks prior to entering the race, leading to an audit report by the Hillsborough County Supervisor of Elections. The qualification decision will affect his ability to run in the upcoming special election.

stories.headline: Here's who's running to fill seat in District 5
stories.summary: A special election is scheduled for September 9 to fill the City Council District 5 seat after the passing of Gwen Henderson. Several candidates, including Ariel Amirah Danley and Orlando Gudes, have announced their intention to run. The election will determine who will complete Henderson’s term and represent areas such as Ybor City, East Tampa, and West Tampa.

stories.headline: Harrowing stories of rescues emerge
stories.summary: In the aftermath of severe flooding in Kerrville, Texas, numerous rescues have been conducted for people stranded by rising waters. Over 160 individuals remain missing after the disaster, which is the deadliest from inland flooding in the U.S. since 1976. Emergency crews continue searching and recovering those affected along the Guadalupe River.

stories.headline: Sheriff's lawyers contest claims
stories.summary: Lawyers for Sheriff Alfred Montgomery contested a removal suit filed by the Missouri Attorney General's Office, which accused the sheriff of violating ethics rules by misrepresenting family relations in court documents. The case involves allegations of Montgomery falsely claiming that his half-brother was not the father of his deputy, Malik Taylor. The first hearing is scheduled for November 10 after arguments on the matter.

stories.headline: Plan to relocate schools fails
stories.summary: A plan to relocate seven tornado-damaged St. Louis Public Schools buildings has been put on hold due to safety and consultation concerns from teachers, union leaders, and parents. The St. Louis Public Schools board decided against relocation without broader community input, fearing dangerous conditions for staff and students if moved too quickly. Negotiations continue amid ongoing discussions about how to best address damaged school facilities.

stories.headline: Mo. officials reject push to crack down on factory farms
stories.summary: A Missouri commission overseeing clean water laws rejected requests to implement stricter environmental rules for factory farms. The decision was based on concerns from farming groups who argued the proposed changes would be difficult to enforce and were not necessary. Commissioners emphasized the need to maintain existing regulations rather than imposing stricter ones at this time.

stories.headline: Arch group closes deal to purchase Millennium
stories.summary: The Gateway Arch Park Foundation finalized its acquisition of the long-closed Millennium Hotel in downtown St. Louis. The nonprofit plans to redevelop the property to enhance the city’s Arch grounds, with plans including transforming the site into a mixed-use area with offices, an amphitheater, a food hall, and other amenities. The $7.5 million purchase is seen as a significant step towards revitalizing downtown St. Louis.

stories.headline: Firefighter honored
stories.summary: A ceremony was held honoring the late St. Louis firefighter Lee M. Kraus, a 30-year veteran of the department who died in the line of duty on July 1, 2025. Family, fellow firefighters, and community members gathered to pay tribute to Kraus' service and dedication.

stories.headline: Nvidia Is First to $4 Trillion
stories.summary: Nvidia became the first company in history to reach a market value of $4 trillion, surpassing Apple and Microsoft. This milestone was driven by the surge in artificial intelligence technology, which Nvidia powers through its graphics processors used in AI chips. The company recently closed trading with a valuation of $4 trillion, reflecting its dominant position and success in the technology market.

stories.headline: Yaccarino Steps Down As CEO of Musk’s X
stories.summary: Linda Yaccarino announced her resignation as CEO of the social-media platform X, following the merger of XAI and X. Yaccarino's departure comes amid uncertainties around the company and its future direction under Elon Musk's leadership. Her exit is expected to affect the platform's management and strategic decisions going forward.

stories.headline: Israel’s Agonizing Choice Over Hostages: ‘It’s Schindler’s List’
stories.summary: Israel faces a painful dilemma over the fate of 20 hostages held by Hamas in Gaza. The government and families are divided on how to handle negotiations and rescue efforts, with many fearing the worst due to harsh conditions of captivity. The situation evokes comparisons to historic rescue operations in dire circumstances, reflecting the deep emotional and political complexities involved.

stories.headline: Two Kevins Are Vying To Head The Fed
stories.summary: Kevin Hassett and Kevin Warsh are competing to become the next chairman of the Federal Reserve. This leadership decision is significant as it will influence the Fed's direction on economic policies, including interest rates and inflation control. The choice reflects the ongoing political and economic debate within the United States regarding monetary policy and economic growth.

stories.headline: A Syrian Death Factory Gives Up Its Secrets; ‘Symbol of Shame’
stories.summary: The Saydnaya prison near Damascus, Syria, once a notorious death factory under the Assad regime, is now revealing its grim secrets. The prison was used as a mass killing site where thousands of detainees were executed, often by hanging. Witness accounts and documents detail the horrific conditions and the scope of the atrocities committed, highlighting the prison as a symbol of shame in Syria's dark history.

stories.headline: Trump set to restart federal layoffs
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has the authority to lay off federal workers and reorganize the federal government in a way not seen in over 100 years, as granted temporarily by the Supreme Court. The administration plans to resume large-scale layoffs across the federal government, despite criticism and legal challenges. Trump began mass layoffs after signing an executive order in February, calling for agencies to reduce ranks of government employees.

stories.headline: AI therapist may help, but there are risks, experts say
stories.summary: Ellie Doyle uses the AI chatbot ChatGPT daily for ideas and communication help, such as reprising her thoughts in conversations with her husband. While the AI offers positive and effective conversational assistance, experts caution there are risks involved with using AI as a therapeutic tool. Dialogue with AI can support users but should be approached with awareness of limitations.

stories.headline: Man who lost family in 2015 answers the call in Texas
stories.summary: Jonathan McComb, who lost his family in the deadly 2015 floods in Wimberley, Texas, works tirelessly as a volunteer in flood rescue efforts on the Guadalupe River near Kerr County. He spends nearly every week searching for flood victims, demonstrating physical and emotional resilience as he helps others recover from devastating floods that have caused significant loss of life and property in the region.

stories.headline: For state's farmers, migrant laborers are 'irreplaceable'
stories.summary: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins emphasizes the indispensable role of migrant laborers for California's farming industry, noting that efforts to replace them with Medicaid recipients or machines are unrealistic. The article includes comments on labor shortages, immigration raids, and the critical dependence on migrant workers for crop cultivation.

stories.headline: A lawman on the surface, but El Diablo underneath
stories.summary: The profile article reveals the double life of Edgar Veytia, a former Mexican lawman turned drug lord known as El Diablo. It details his criminal activities, including kidnapping and drug trafficking, his arrest in 2017, and ongoing legal repercussions. The story explores the contrast between his public persona and his violent criminal undertakings.

stories.headline: Stephen Miller’s L.A. revenge plot plays out
stories.summary: The piece highlights renewed attention on Stephen Miller, a former White House deputy chief of staff with roots in Santa Monica, focusing on his role in shaping aggressive immigration policies and his controversial reputation. It covers local reactions, protests, and the ongoing impact of his political actions.

stories.headline: Will tax credits help soundstage owners?
stories.summary: The article analyzes whether tax credits can support owners of soundstages in Los Angeles whose industry has suffered setbacks due to the pandemic and other economic challenges. It notes declines in film shoots and other production activities and explores whether recent measures can help revive the sector's capacity and profitability.

stories.headline: Six months after the fires, progress is painful and hard
stories.summary: The article discusses the difficult recovery process six months after the devastating fires along the Pacific Coast in Los Angeles County. It highlights the slow progress in cleanup, investigations, and lawsuits, and describes how areas like Palisades are becoming symbols of hope yet still face significant challenges including rebuilding, assessing financial losses, and navigating insurance claims.

stories.headline: White House sees raids as a 'grand success'
stories.summary: The White House considers recent raids involving National Guard troops and immigration agents in Los Angeles a political success despite some risks. The operations targeted President Trump's political opponents and have intensified enforcement efforts amid controversy, with political implications as the administration manages public reaction and ongoing investigations.

stories.headline: DMPS to go ahead with cheaper overhaul
stories.summary: Des Moines Public Schools officials plan to move forward with a scaled-back $265 million bond proposal to overhaul the district’s infrastructure, down from an original $500 million plan. The revised plan reduces the number of new schools and extends the timeline for renovation projects. The bond aims to improve learning environments, expand pre-kindergarten and preschool programs, and upgrade facilities over the next 5 years. School board members support the more affordable approach to enhance student outcomes and boost enrollment.

stories.headline: Nitrate levels fall, but central Iowa watering ban still enforced
stories.summary: Although nitrate levels in the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers have dipped below the threshold needed to lift the lawn watering ban, Central Iowa Water Works continues the ban to sustain water quality. Officials note nitrate readings remain just below the limit, and demand for water remains high. Most residents are complying, though a few receive violations. The ban remains until further assessment ensures safety and compliance.

stories.headline: What solutions exist for metro’s water woes?
stories.summary: The Central Iowa Water Works is imposing an unprecedented lawn-watering ban on its 600,000 customers following a surge in nitrate levels in local rivers. Experts debate the cause and solutions, including equipment limitations and fertilizer runoff. Some officials urge stricter conservation, while others call for balance to maintain water supply. The dilemma highlights tensions between environmental protection and practical management of water resources.

stories.headline: Search for missing in Texas to become more daunting in heat
stories.summary: The ongoing search for missing persons in Texas is expected to become more difficult as high heat intensifies conditions. Rescue teams are preparing for increased challenges while continuing efforts. The situation underscores the risks posed by extreme weather during emergency operations.

stories.headline: Hunt community leans on each other
stories.summary: Residents of Hunt, particularly 77-year-old Rena Bailey, are showing resilience and support for one another in the aftermath of severe flooding that destroyed the Hunt Store. The community has been united by shared hardships and the emotional impact of the disaster, helping residents cope with the ongoing challenges.

stories.headline: Moody developer indicted in alleged bid rig
stories.summary: The developer and operator of the Moody Center has been indicted by a federal grand jury for alleged bid-rigging related to the arena's development. Tim Leiweke, CEO of Oak View Group, faces conspiracy charges connected to rigging bids in the University of Texas basketball arena project. Officials cite violations of fair bidding processes and misuse of contractors and funding.

stories.headline: Questions linger over warnings, response
stories.summary: There are ongoing questions about the adequacy of disaster response and warnings during the Kerr County floods. Experts note that forecasting agencies provided timely scientific data, but challenges remain in mobilizing a local response to effectively protect and inform citizens ahead of the devastating flood event.

stories.headline: More rain and tears as search pushes on
stories.summary: As thunderstorms continue in Texas, search and recovery efforts intensify following catastrophic flooding that identified multiple victims and left many missing across Travis, Williamson, and Burnet counties. The death toll rises to 109 with authorities and volunteers working to repair damage and assist those affected.

stories.headline: ‘That was not her’
stories.summary: Wendy Tolbert is devastated after her 4-year-old son Jordan Wallace was fatally stabbed by his mother allegedly during an emotional and mental health collapse. The mother also attacked two other children before setting their Logan Square home on fire. Police and family describe the mother as suffering from acute mental health issues and claim she has never been abusive to the children but was overwhelmed by her condition.

stories.headline: These rodents cut their teeth on the streets of Chicago
stories.summary: A Field Museum study reveals that Chicago's urban environment is influencing the evolution of city rodents like chipmunks and voles. Comparing skulls of recent specimens with those from over a century ago, researchers found modern rodents have adapted their teeth and skull structure to their urban habitats, showing an evolutionary response to living in parks and bushes of the city.

stories.headline: Judge rules ex-alderman unfit for trial
stories.summary: A federal judge has ruled that former Chicago Alderman Carrie Austin is medically unfit to stand trial on long-pending corruption charges. The decision was based on Austin's chronic health issues, including pulmonary disease and cancer, which make her unlikely to survive a trial. This ruling likely ends a case first opened six years ago involving alleged corruption during her time in office.

stories.headline: Measles outbreak worst in decades
stories.summary: The U.S. is facing its worst measles outbreak in 25 years, after the disease was declared eliminated in 2000. Experts warn this grim milestone reflects alarming setbacks in vaccination rates, with outbreaks now spreading across 38 states. The resurgence signals the potential for measles to become endemic again, threatening public health especially in vulnerable communities.

stories.headline: CNN names Ithaca best town to visit
stories.summary: Ithaca has been ranked the top town on CNN Travel's 2025 list of Best Towns in America to Visit, praised for its natural beauty, vibrant cultural scene, and diverse experiences. The town is known for its waterfalls, gorges, cultural favorites like the Ithaca Farmers Market, South Hill Cider, historic theaters, and the Dalai Lama Library. Ithaca Commons hosts over 100 shops and restaurants, enhancing its appeal as a college town with a rich variety of activities and dining, including plant-based options and local producers.

stories.headline: Out of school, into debt?
stories.summary: New college graduates, mostly from Gen Z, face significant financial stress as they start their careers, according to Ally Bank's Minds on Money report. Only 34% of adults under 28 feel in control of their finances. Graduates are advised to manage lifestyle creep, plan for student loan repayments, and strategically navigate job interviews by understanding company culture and soft skills importance.

stories.headline: Trump supporters riled over Epstein findings
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s law enforcement officials face criticism from MAGA supporters after an FBI and Justice Department memo concluded Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in 2019 and found no evidence of an Epstein 'clint list.' Supporters are upset over perceived lack of transparency about Epstein’s associates. Conservative activists and Trump allies have called for action against Attorney General Pam Bondi and have urged Vice President JD Vance to support Trump’s stance on this matter.

stories.headline: Measles Cases At High in U.S., Raising Alarm
stories.summary: The United States is experiencing a significant rise in measles cases, the highest since the disease was declared eliminated in 2000. The increase has alarmed public health officials nationwide, with experts warning of potential outbreaks and emphasizing vaccination to control the spread. The outbreak is putting additional pressure on health departments.

stories.headline: Right-Wing Bullhorn Has Only Ear That Matters
stories.summary: Laura Loomer, a right-wing activist known for her confrontational style and national security advocacy, showcased her persistence and influence in conservative circles. Despite controversies and resistance, she continues to push her agenda, receiving support from key political figures, and striving to impact the political landscape.

stories.headline: Musk's X Chief Announces Exit After Two Years
stories.summary: Linda Yaccarino, the chief executive officer and a top lieutenant to Elon Musk, announced her departure from X (formerly Twitter) after two years. Yaccarino expressed gratitude for her tenure and denied any conflicts with Musk, who has taken over leadership. The exit follows a series of changes and challenges within the company since Musk's acquisition.

stories.headline: In Texas Hill Country, Rivers Bring Magnetic Allure, and Danger
stories.summary: The San Marcos and Blanco rivers in Texas Hill Country attract many visitors due to their natural beauty, but the rivers also pose risks, especially from flooding caused by summer storms. Experts highlight dangers such as flash floods and note the similarity of the region's floodwaters to those experienced in other states, emphasizing the need for caution in this popular area.

stories.headline: Trump Law Imperils Care For 1.5 Million in New York
stories.summary: President Trump's domestic policy law, which reduces federal tax cuts and slashes social safety nets, will severely impact health insurance and Medicaid coverage in New York, potentially harming over one million people. Experts warn of drastic cuts to health care funds for lower-income groups, middle-class, and wealthy patients, resulting in diminished care and major challenges for hospitals and health advocates.

stories.headline: Floodwaters Moved Faster Than Niagara Falls
stories.summary: The flood flow rate of the Guadalupe River quickly exceeded a small stream to a torrent of 120,000 cubic feet per second, causing widespread destruction and flooding which severely impacted many people, including children.

stories.headline: Molding the Next Manning
stories.summary: Arch Manning, a promising young football quarterback from Texas, is gaining attention for his talent as he prepares for a future in professional football, continuing the legacy of his family.

stories.headline: Zeynep Tufekci Opinion
stories.summary: Zeynep Tufekci provides an opinion piece featured on page A24 addressing current social or political issues with her unique perspective.

stories.headline: Tech in the Service of Dance
stories.summary: Jacob’s Pillow in Massachusetts pioneers technologically advanced dance theater experiences, blending cutting-edge dance with innovative digital artistry to expand the boundaries of performing arts.

stories.headline: 'Till' Star Takes On Cannibals
stories.summary: Actress Danielle Deadwyler stars in a new horror movie titled '40 Acres,' which features a gritty post-apocalyptic story involving cannibalism, marking a new direction in her career in the arts and cinema.

stories.headline: A Trade Deal, to Trump
stories.summary: President Trump engages in global trade negotiations, aiming for advantageous deals though some critics say that his approach is one-sided and aggressive.

stories.headline: Amazon’s Biggest Data Center
stories.summary: Amazon is developing one of the largest computer centers in the U.S. located in Indiana, expanding its data processing capabilities to support its growing business operations.

stories.headline: Clean Energy Line Under Fire
stories.summary: The Grain Belt Express line, intended to carry electricity from wind farms across the Midwest, is facing legal challenges from the Missouri attorney general, putting the future of the project in question.

stories.headline: Putin Escalates Ukraine War
stories.summary: Russian leader Vladimir Putin appears to be escalating the military conflict in Ukraine, signaling a wider war or prolonged engagement. The escalating war raises concerns internationally, especially from the U.S. under President Trump.

stories.headline: Kenyan Protests Turn Deadly
stories.summary: Violent clashes between protesters and police in Kenya have escalated, leading to deadly confrontations amid simmering anger against the government. The unrest highlights deep political tensions and dissatisfaction in the country.

stories.headline: Private Equity Takes the Field In Youth Sports
stories.summary: Private equity is increasingly investing in youth sports, with many young sports fathers seeing this as a new career opportunity or supportive investment. Video clips of youth sports and strong interest from business communities have pushed the development and growth of private equity in sports, raising discussions about the future impact on young athletes and sports culture.

stories.headline: Attack on Ukraine comes as Trump castigates Putin
stories.summary: Russia launched a major wave of drone and missile attacks on Ukraine, striking cities and towns across central and western Ukraine. The attacks coincided with criticism from former President Trump toward Russian President Vladimir Putin. The attacks caused military and logistical disruptions, including explosions near Kyiv. The scale of the attack set records for drones and missiles launched in a single night since the war began.

stories.headline: End of tax breaks for EV drivers could affect California
stories.summary: Federal tax breaks on electric vehicles, including up to $7,500 for new or leased EVs and $4,000 for used EVs, will expire after September 30. This change may increase costs for consumers in California and elsewhere, negatively impacting demand. Energy advocates warn this could hinder efforts to reduce transportation energy burden and help the environment. The tax credits were enacted under President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.

stories.headline: White House sues California over transgender athlete law
stories.summary: The Trump administration has sued California for allowing transgender athletes to compete in K-12 sports, following threats of legal action. The Department of Justice filed suit after California refused to change its policy allowing student-athletes to compete on sports teams that align with their gender identity. Education Secretary Linda McMahon and Attorney General Pam Bondi criticized California's refusal to comply with federal guidelines and Title IX provisions.

stories.headline: At least 173 still missing after Texas floods
stories.summary: Search crews found no new signs of the scores of people missing after devastating floods struck Texas Hill County. Governor Greg Abbott revealed the number of missing was at least 173, more than twice the officially acknowledged figure. Efforts continue to locate all those affected by the floods, which have resulted in numerous deaths, including many children. The disaster response has faced scrutiny regarding federal and local coordination.

stories.headline: Mass. officials hone plan ahead of Medicaid changes
stories.summary: Massachusetts officials are preparing for significant outreach to help residents maintain Medicaid coverage amid new requirements set by President Trump. An estimated 300,000 people risk losing coverage over the next decade. State health officials have expressed concern about potential gaps in care and increased strain on healthcare providers if newly uninsured individuals do not receive timely support.

stories.headline: Unswayed by Trump, Putin hits Ukraine
stories.summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin remains resolute in his military campaign against Ukraine despite pressure from U.S. President Trump and ongoing diplomatic efforts. Analysts indicate Putin's focus on battlefield superiority and nuclear diplomacy signals a willingness to continue conflict with little inclination to negotiate under current conditions.

stories.headline: AG ready to defend in-state tuition for noncitizens
stories.summary: Massachusetts Attorney General plans to legally defend a state law allowing certain undocumented immigrants to pay in-state tuition at public colleges and universities. The challenge comes amid increased federal enforcement against undocumented immigrants and attempts to end similar tuition benefits in other states. The lawsuit addresses claims of discrimination but argues for equal access to education for qualified students.

stories.headline: MESSI (AND MIAMI) IN FOXBOROUGH
stories.summary: Soccer superstar Lionel Messi celebrated scoring his second goal of the night as he led Inter Miami to a 2-1 victory over the Revolution at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, highlighting Miami’s competitive performance in the match.

stories.headline: Health care giants boost Beacon Hill politicians
stories.summary: A Globe analysis reveals that major health care companies, notably Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, have significantly increased their political donations to influential Massachusetts lawmakers on Beacon Hill. The donations coincide with a volatile medical market and highlight how industry influence shapes policy and legislation. The companies’ contributions focus particularly on key officials in the health care and insurance sectors.
people: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts

stories.headline: White House ups Harvard fight
stories.summary: The Trump administration has escalated its scrutiny of Harvard University by challenging its accreditation and subpoenaing international student data. The Departments of Education and Homeland Security are investigating alleged federal civil rights violations and anti-semitism concerns, with scrutiny on Harvard's handling of research funding and international student information. Harvard contests the administration's actions as improper and politically motivated.

stories.headline: Brothers believed killed in explosion
stories.summary: Three brothers, Jesus Ramos, Jhony Ramos, and Joel Melendez, are believed to have died in a fireworks warehouse explosion in Yolo County. They were among seven people missing after the blast in the rural community of Esparto. Family and community members mourn the loss while authorities continue the investigation and await DNA analysis for official confirmation.

stories.headline: Vaillancourt fountain missing from park plans
stories.summary: The controversial Vaillancourt Fountain in San Francisco faces removal from the Embarcadero Plaza renovation project due to high restoration costs estimated at $29 million, nearly matching the entire renovation budget. City officials and community members debate preserving the brutalist sculpture amidst concerns over its condition and expense to restore.

stories.headline: Palisades Fire suit levels new claims
stories.summary: A fire lawsuit related to the Palisades Fire alleges negligence against Los Angeles city agencies and the California Department of Parks and Recreation, citing a catastrophic chain of mistakes starting on New Year’s fire. The fire destroyed over 6,800 homes and businesses and killed 12 people. Victims claim inadequate water supply and poor firefighting resources contributed to the disaster.

stories.headline: Home linked to fireworks firm’s owner is raided
stories.summary: Police raided a San Francisco home connected to the owner of the fireworks company whose warehouse exploded causing multiple deaths. Search efforts included cooperation with various law enforcement agencies. The home’s owner, a licensed fireworks dealer, had their license denied two years ago. Officials reported no law enforcement presence at the house after the raid.

stories.headline: Nonprofit faces off-pitch challenges
stories.summary: Soccer Without Borders, a nonprofit serving newcomer immigrants and refugees, faces real-world anxiety and operational challenges while playing through anxious times in Oakland. The organization helps teenage boys from various countries who come to the U.S., providing them a positive outlet through soccer amidst their personal struggles.

stories.headline: Arts, Beats & Eats fest lands a new sponsor
stories.summary: The Arts, Beats & Eats festival, facing funding challenges, has secured a new title sponsor, Michigan Lottery, for its popular Labor Day weekend event. Michigan Lottery will replace Soaring Eagle Casino & Resort as the main sponsor and will support the festival through 2027. The newly rebranded event will be called Michigan Lottery Arts, Beats & Eats presented by Flagstar Bank, continuing the festival's tradition amid a changing sponsorship landscape.

stories.headline: McLaren nurses strike: Fix staffing
stories.summary: Registered nurses and service group employees at McLaren Macomb Hospital in Mount Clemens have been on strike for three days, demanding better staffing and safer work conditions. The strike involves over 660 union members from the Office and Professional Employees International Union (OPEIU) Local 40. Union leaders call out unfair labor practices that hinder safe staffing ratios and patient care, while nurses are not expected to return to work until the weekend.

stories.headline: Texas camp staff saved many from flood
stories.summary: During severe flooding at Camp La Junta in Texas caused by rising water levels from the Guadalupe River, camp staff acted quickly to save hundreds of boys from disaster. Despite floodwaters breaking into cabins, counselors bravely rescued boys by moving them to safety in high places and rafting them to safety. The staff's swift and decisive actions during the flood ensured that all nearly 400 children and counselors at the all-boys camp remained accounted for and safe.
